key_findings: The Medical World Model (MeWM) introduces the first world model in medicine that visually predicts future disease states based on clinical decisions, combining vision-language models as policy generators with tumor generative models as dynamics simulators for treatment planning.

The system comprises two key components: policy models that generate clinical treatment action plans, and dynamics models that simulate tumor progression or regression under specific treatment conditions, enabling predictive medical decision-making.

An inverse dynamics model applies survival analysis to simulated post-treatment tumors, enabling quantitative evaluation of treatment efficacy. This approach allows clinicians to assess potential treatment outcomes before implementation, potentially improving patient care through data-driven decision support.

The implementation leverages recent advances in large generative models, specifically adapting vision-language architectures for medical applications. The system requires integration of clinical imaging data with treatment protocols, demanding substantial computational resources for real-time tumor simulation. The approach necessitates training on large medical datasets with longitudinal patient data to achieve reliable predictive accuracy for clinical deployment.

This work establishes a foundation for AI-assisted clinical decision-making in oncology, potentially transforming treatment planning workflows by providing visual predictions of disease progression under different therapeutic interventions.
limitations: Limited information provided about validation methodology and clinical accuracy metrics
Unclear scalability across different tumor types and patient populations
problem_addressed: Simulating disease dynamics and tumor evolution for clinical decision-making and treatment planning in oncology
